results.title: Jacques le Fataliste et Son Maitre
results.brief_description:
Jacques, who believes in fate, is involved in an endless argument with his master, who does not, as they journey along retelling the stories of their lives and loves.

Credits: Director, Pierre Cardinal ; photography, Jacques Lemare.
Cast: Marie Dubois, Margo Lion, Alexandre Rignault, Claude Gensac, Madeleine Renaud, Jacques Castelot, Jean Paredes.

results.title: Jacques Henri Lartigue, Peintre et Photographe
results.brief_description:
“If we think of photography as a documentary art, our attention is likely to focus first on images of battle or disaster, deprivation or unrest. Indeed, outside the familiar confines of the family album or the surreal arena of celebrity, archival photographs most powerfully frame gritty realities our eyes might otherwise avoid. Not so with the pictures of Jacques Henri Lartigue (1894-1986), who produced stunning and sophisticated images from the time he was seven years old. Lartigue was in love with motion, and his subjects cars racing, flying machines and glider planes, people jumping, fashionable ladies strolling in the park, vacationers at the seashore and the races embody the exhilaration of movement. Zany and amusing, Lartigue’s work seems a testament to happiness itself, and this book with 126 duotone photos and 16 gatefolds is a fitting celebration of his legacy.” Reference: Vicki Goldberg. ‘Jacques Henri Lartigue, photographer’. Bulfinch Press, 1998.

Credits: Producer, Bernard Meusnier ; director, Francois Reichenbach ; photographer, Francois Reichenbach, Gerard de Battista.
Cast: Interviewees include Michel Tournier, Jean-Michel Folon and Charlotte Rampling.

results.title: Jacques-Louis David (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Colin Clark, John Brabourne Productions and Visual Programme Systems
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Romantic vs classic art”.
Looks at some famous works of the French artist, Jacques-Louis David, which bear all the strengths and weaknesses of Classicism. Narrated by Kenneth Clark.

results.title: Jacqueline du Pre
results.brief_description: Jacqueline du Pre, a sixteen year old girl who was a pupil of Pablo Casals and described by critics as one of the world’s greatest cellists. Accompanied by Iris du Pre on the piano, she plays ‘Song Without Words’ Opus 109 by Mendelsohn, ‘Intermezzo’ from ‘Goyescas’ by Granados and ‘Allegro Appassionato’ by Saint-Saens. Presented by Patricia Foy.

results.title: Jacob: 'Everybody's allowed to cry'
results.creator_credit: South Australian Film Corporation, Australian Film Commission and Lyn Bugden
results.brief_description: A moving documentation of the life of a small boy about to face his sixth major operation in six years. Raises questions of care for the hospitalised, the rights of the patient and family, and the emotional requirements of people reliant on technology for life support. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Jacob's ladder
results.creator_credit: Alan Marshall, Carolco Pictures and Adrian Lyne
results.brief_description: Jacob Singer is a Vietnam veteran working as a postman who is deeply haunted by a horrible experience in battle, the details of which he cannot clearly recall. When strange and violent hallucinations begin to invade his everyday life, together with the discovery that his fellow battalion members are also seeing the same demons, he begins to suspect covert Army involvement. As the visions become darker and more terrifying, he suffers severe panic attacks related to the chaos that may be reality or that may merely exist in his own mind. Cast includes: Tim Robbins, Elizabeth Pena, Danny Aiello, Matt Craven, Pruitt Taylor Vince and Jason Alexander.

results.title: Jacob's dream
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Alan Madden
results.brief_description: In both his sleeping and waking hours, Jacob encounters a character who provides the basis for the script of his short film; an assessment panel is not impressed. Cast includes John Penman, Bryon Williams, Edward Rosser, John Phillips, Taylor Owynns. Cinematography by Peter Tammer. Music composed and conducted by Christopher Gordon.

results.title: Jacky visits the zoo
results.creator_credit: Richard Gilbert, ONF | NFB and Mort Ransen
results.brief_description: A tour of the zoo is given considerable momentum as an irate keeper chases Jacky for teasing the animals. The camera catches good close-ups of the zoo’s polar bear, lion, giraffe, elephant, rhinoceros, camel, zebra and finally Jacky, in a cage labelled “Wild Boy.” Piano soundtrack, no dialogue. (Award: Rome)

results.title: Jackson Pollock What Kind of Risk
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Risk”.
Jackson Pollock (1912-1956) was the leading exponent of what is usually called Abstract Expressionist Art. Charles Harrison examines a number of Pollock’s paintings, and discusses how they were made and what they represent. Includes some film of Pollock himself working on a painting in 1952
